title: How a summer job turned into a 2000-person ice cream empire | (w/ Ben Van Leeuwen) Masters of Scale

rawLines.text: We bought two used post office trucks on
eBay. One was five on eBay.
You bought them on eBay?
We bought them on eBay. It was click
click deliver it here. They were about a
truck. Um and one was $2,500, one was
$5,000. We found someone in Atoria,
Queens to retrofit them into ice cream
trucks. You know, all the credit cards
were maxed out, everything. You notice
on day one, we probably had, you know,
$500 in our bank accounts collectively.
a week before Christmas, maybe gosh,
probably only like 10 years ago. Um,
there was no finance team, you know, I
did the books and I said, "Wait a
minute,
we're going to be negative, you know,
$200,000 in a week." And I'm like,
"Shit,
not a good moment."
Yeah. Not a good moment. I don't know
how we got here, but that's not going to
work, right?
How big is the business today?
So, in 2025, we started with 70
corporateowned scoop shops. will open 35
this year. So, we'll actually grow 50%
on our scoop shop footprint this year.
Um, wholesale is in 15,000 doors with
over 50 SKUs. Um, we I think by July
we'll hit about 2,000 total team
members. Um, most of that are in the
retail stores. Um,
so growing rapidly. I'm Jeff Burman,
your host. This week on the show, a
conversation with the CEO and co-founder
of Venluan Ice Cream, Ben Venluan. He's
the mad scientist behind the company's
wildest flavors. You may have seen their
viral craft mac and cheese or Hidden
Valley Ranch ice creams online and also
its incredibly delicious approach to
classics. The New York Times wire cutter
called its vanilla the very best on the
market. Fair warning, this episode might
make you drool.
This is Masters of Scale,
Ben. Welcome to Masters of Scale.
Thank you.
I uh I love your product. It is so much
fun for me when I get to have a
conversation with a with a founder, with
an entrepreneur who who um has started a
company that I'm just I I just love. Uh
so the starting an ice cream company is
not not the obvious path for every
entrepreneur. Take me back. Where where
did where did this come from?
Entrepreneurial drive. I think it's in
my blood. My dad has been a serial
entrepreneur
since
C R I A L, not C E R E.
Yes. Yes. Yes. Exactly. Since he was in
high school. Um, so yeah, I think it's
part of my DNA. But Vanlu ice cream
actually came from my first summer job
before college. That was the impetus. I
drove a Good Humor ice cream truck where
I grew up in Greenwich, Connecticut. And
I loved it. I loved the hospitality
aspect, interacting with people. Um, the
product itself was prepackaged
strawberry shortcake bars, which
actually Vanluan makes a Vanluan version
of that now, which is really good. Um,
I was always partial to the Good Humor
Chocolate Clair bars. Those were those
were my favorites.
Yeah, really good.
Um, I did that for two summers. After
the second summer of doing that, I
decided I didn't want to go back to
college. Um, I had saved up enough money
from driving that truck to go
backpacking throughout Europe and
Southeast Asia.
Um, but that was a very formative
experience and the decision to do that
kind of changed the course of my entire
life because it wasn't a rational
decision like especially having grown up
in Greenwich, Connecticut, an
environment where it's amazing, you
know, ambitious, people are interesting
and um just want to do big things. Um,
but that path there, at least the way I
saw it, was you go to the best college
you can, you get the best grades you
can, and you hopefully get a job in
finance, right? Um, or maybe law or
maybe medicine. Um, I never had great
grades, maybe 2.8, 2.9 GPA. Um,
so when I decided to go travel, you
know, it was sort of the opposite of
that path. And I wanted friends to come
along with me. I didn't want to go
alone. like I'm a really social person.
I don't do well on my own. Um but all of
my friends, you know, all these guys are
still like some of my best friends on
earth were like, "No, no, Ben, we can't
do that. You know, this is it's going to
look so bad on our resumes to take a
year off college." And I was like, "But
I want to do it." So, I think the lesson
there was like go with what attracts. I
guarantee you if I didn't go on that
trip, I wouldn't have started an ice
cream company.
Why? Why not? Um, a it was formative in
like learning about food and learning
about really good ingredients. But more
than that, why is Vanluen going to open
its hundth store this year? Not because
we're brilliant, not because we came up
with an incredibly novel product, but
Vanlu's going to open their hundth store
this year and we're going to be the
almost biggest artisal ice cream company
in the US, the biggest consumer market
on Earth, simply because we decided to
do it.
Yeah. I mean, I think there's a lot to
be said for it's not just making a
decision. It's making a decision that
flies in the face of everything you've
been raised to do, you've seen around
you, the definition of success around
you. It sounds like you really just
listened to what was inside of you. And
even when you couldn't persuade a friend
to join you, you were like, I'm doing
it. I'm going
totally.
So, on that trip through Europe, through
Southeast Asia, what did you learn about
food and ingredients? And then what did
you learn about yourself?
What struck me the most about food
particularly like in I remember going
you know to the first grocery store I'
ever been to in Italy and it wasn't a
fancy grocery store. They don't really
have fancy grocery stores there yet
every grocery store is almost as fancy
as the fanciest store in America cuz I
always say there's no foodies in Italy.
It's just Italians, right?
like yes, you care about your olive oil
and your cheese and the quality of your
pasta and that without even realizing it
then I was like it is so it was so
exciting to me that food this thing you
do three times a day which is something
I was excited about is normal to be
excited about in other places and to
care about and to put a lot of time into
and to you know value you know in a
really high way right because I value it
a lot I mean my my food experience is
every day It's like, you know, some of
the most important parts of my day is
eating and what am I going to eat? Um,
so I learned a lot about that there.
So you you you came back to the States
from your travels. At what point did you
say we're really going to do this? I'm
going to I'm going to launch an ice
cream.
Well, I came back to the States for my
travels. I went to college. I finished
college. Um, I really looked up to my
sister after college. She worked at
Goldman Sachs. Then she worked at
Newberger Berman. and she started her
own private wealth management firm and
I looked up to Jenny because she was
really responsible and she made a good
living and I said I want to do that
and I didn't really think it through
because I didn't have great grades. I'd
done no internships. Um so I said Jenny
can you help me get a job like one of
the ones you had and she's like no you
know she's like I I can try but it
doesn't work that way.
And after meeting her one day in the
city I saw Mr. softy truck. And in that
moment, um, I always say I didn't have
an idea in that moment. I made a
decision in that moment. So, so that's
where the decision piece comes in. For
some reason, I I didn't say, "Oh, I have
an idea to start an ice cream company."
I said, "Oh, that's what I'm going to
do." It was so clear and I was so
excited. I saw this Mr. Softy truck. And
by the way, I don't think this was a
great idea. But I said, I'm gonna get an
ice cream truck and I'm gonna learn how
to make ice cream and I'm gonna find the
best ingredients I can and I'm gonna
sell that ice cream off this truck.
And had you made ice cream before
no history? So I mean, where do you even
start then?
Long before I had made ice cream, I
started writing the business plan.
His brother Pete and his then romantic
partner Laura O'Neal loved the idea too.
They became Ben's co-founders.
And then once we had more confidence
that we could do it, I said, "Okay, we
better figure out how to make the ice
cream."
What year are we in?
2007. I had Thomas Skeller's Bushon
cookbook. Okay.
Um, not a pastry book, but there was a
recipe for cremeong glaze, which you can
turn into vanilla ice cream in there,
right?
And I made that and had a lot of cream
and a lot of eggs. And what was really
exciting about making that and tasting,
we said, "Whoa, this is, you know, the
best vanilla ice cream I've ever had."
Huh.
And it was really easy to make. And all
it has is cream, eggs, sugar, milk,
little bit of sea salt, and whole
vanilla beans.
Um, and you put it in the freezer and it
stays good for months or years. So,
we're like, "Wo, you can make the best
ice cream ever
and it's completely preservable. You
don't need to add any weird stuff."
Okay. So, you you you've got a business
plan. You've got a recipe for one ice
cream.
What's what's the leap to actually
starting a company, raising money,
figuring out your supply chain, all of
that? Like h how did you get from A to B
there?
For some reason, we came up with a
quarter million is the number.
Okay.
Um you know, it would be enough to buy a
brand new Chevrolet truck, pay a lot to
turn it into an ice cream truck. Um you
know, probably have a h 100,000 bucks on
the balance sheet to get us through the
first year or two if we weren't making
money.
and
we set out to try to raise money and
everybody said no.
What What were they telling you when
they were saying no? What were you
hearing?
It's funny. I have such a I I have a way
of not remembering anything that I don't
love
me. I mean, I was I I I was annoyed by
and disappointed, but I wasn't
discouraged. I was never discouraged
just because
yes, I believed in myself, but also it's
like I was like, I'm hardwork. I have a
good pallet.
I know I'm going to be able to sell ice
cream off a truck and make money. You
know, I know I'll be able to pay

kept going. And I had this really
beautiful business plan. It was 60
pages. And at this time, I lived in
Greenpoint with Laura O'Neal, who at
that time we were in a relationship.
Now, we're just co-founders and best
friends on earth. Um,
I want to come back to that in a minute.
So, it was her and I, my brother Peter,
and our friend, one of my best friends,
Ben Colombo, all living in this

McInness in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. So, I
got $2,500 here, $5,000 here, 15 from a

15,000 from one of Lur's best friends

cobbled together only $60,000. So, we
had tried to raise 250, we only raised
60. Um, and that was enough not to buy a
new truck because just the new truck
before you turned it into an ice cream
truck would have been 70,000.
So, we bought a used post office truck.
Actually, we bought two. We started with
two. We because we were like, "Wait,
these used trucks are cheap. Let's just
get two." We bought two used post office
trucks on eBay. One was 5 on eBay.
You bought them one on eBay.
We bought them on eBay. It was click
click. Deliver it here. They arrive on a
truck. Um, and one was $2,500, one was
$5,000. We found someone in Atoria,
Queens to retrofit them into ice cream
trucks. You know, all the credit cards
were maxed out, everything. You notice
on day one, we probably had, you know,
$500 in our bank accounts collectively.
Um,
it was a ton of work though. And and
what I find really striking about what
we were able to do with $60,000 18 years
ago is
I I have so much more experience now. I
know so much more about business. I am,
you know, 50 times more sophisticated in
every business department. Yet, I don't
think
I could do half of what I did then with
60,000 with even half a million dollars
today.
Why is that? It's a weird phenomenon.
Yeah.
I think when you're, you know, part of
it is is age. When you're that young,
you know, there's a different kind of
energy. Part of it is an age, but it's
just the hunger and the pressure to have
to do it. But I mean, what we accomplish
with that, like the website we built,
the graphic design we did, the
marketing, the product development. Um,
I'm struck by how much we could do with
so little.
Um, but I think this phenomenon, you
know, you see it in business. This is
why the unilvers, the Nestle's
cannot do what we did, you know, cannot
start it even with all the resources in
the world. Like when you get big, your
your brain changes. You know, you're
really good. You become good at running
big organizations, but harder at
starting something in a scrappy way.
So you've got 60 grand, you got two
trucks, you got someone in Atoria,
Queens who's who's making them work for
ice cream. You got 500 bucks left. How
do you get to market?
Day one
we
Well, getting to day one was hard. You

Mhm. And are you manufacturing in a home

you're manufacturing in a c-acker in

you know, hundreds of thousands of
dollars
recipe testing? Had you like like where

incredibly extensive and exhaustive

recipes with 15 different kinds of

We narrowed it down to 10. So, I think
we had 10 chocolates that we loved. We
had 10 vanillaas, we had five mint

know, so we had probably a hundred

the greatest party ever.
Oh, it was awesome. And we had everybody

do you like? What do you like? Um, so we
did really really rigorous, you know,
market testing, you know, for no money.
And and that's sort of where I'm getting
back. Like if if Vanluen were to attempt
to do that now in a regular way that
that, you know, that study would cost 30
You're waiting on the permit.
We're waiting on the permit. you're
you've got a co-acking location up.
Every week we're going to try to get the
permit, but then the person doesn't show
up. So, it's really discouraging and
then finally after 6 weeks of doing
this, it's late June, it's almost July,
so like missed those great spring
months. Um, and we knew about this
because we had run the Good Humor
Trucks. So, we knew, you know, you have
four months of really, really good
sales. Um, then finally, I think it was
June 21st, we get our permit, and we are
so excited. So, we get the permit on
this first truck. Finally, we parked on
the corner of Green and Prince and Soho.
And by the time we opened the window,
there was like a line of 15 people.
Um, and why' it work, right? Why'd it
work right away? The truck looked really
nice. It had this beautiful solid
butcher block counter. Um, so it had a
homeier feel than most food trucks.
And we were serving 10 flavors of ice
cream. So, Hudson Valley Red Currant,
Sicilian Pistachio, a really good
Michelle Kazelle chocolate, but it
worked, I think, because of the
distinctness of the truck. And then
people were
happy to have a product, I think, that
was so clean label, not because the
label read, but because I really still
believe like the best ice cream is made
with just milk, cream, sugar, eggs, and,
you know, a little bit of salt, but
nothing else. I like it better without
the stabilizers.
Did you come back to that location the
very next day? Did that become the
truck?
It became the location for I think our
first 3 or 4 years. It was Green and
Prince every day from 10:00 a.m. till
5:00 p.m. 6:00 p.m. And then Soho would
kind of die cuz it was mostly retail
driven. Um and then we would drive up to
University and 12th Street. University
and 12th or 11th
um in Greenwich Village and stay there
till midnight.
Venluins started as a family business.
Ben's co-founders were his brother Pete
and his then girlfriend Laura O'Neal.
Ben and Laura got married the same week
they started the company in 2008. They
divorced a few years later, but they
remain co-founders. She now describes
him as a best friend and business
soulmate. All right, so let's talk about
Laura for a second. Um, uh, you went on
to marry Laura.
Yes. Um, uh, we had Estair Pell on the
show recently and, uh, she talks about
how 65% of of startups that fail fail
because of co-founder relationships
falling apart. Um, you and Laura ended
up getting divorced, but you talk about
her as your best friend. You've remained
business partners. H how I I think for
anyone who's been divorced, for a lot of
people divorced, this is hard to
imagine. How have you managed to make
this work?
Um, I mean it wasn't hard at all. I mean
it was effortless. Um, I mean we were
very young when we got married. Laura's
from Australia. Um,
but we wanted to continue running the
business together. We were really
excited about it. Um, and we just
continued being great friends and doing
things together. Um, Laura and her
partner Greg who are like my family have
a four-year-old. Um, I'm super close
with her. Um, so yeah, they're I mean
we're best friends but also like family.
Was there a concern when you guys were
separating on the personal side that
would affect the business side?
Zero concern. Yeah. I mean I do I do
hear about the stories of founder strife
and I have my like you know so many
gripes around you know working with my
brother. It's not always easy. With all
that said, the three of us are so
aligned in our work ethic and knowing
that we're never going anywhere. Um, but
not because it's easy, right? You know,
there's days where I'm like, is is this
worth it? Like, is it worth it trying to
build, you know, 200 ice cream stores in
the next 2 and 1/2 years? Um, but with
that said, we're completely similar in
our
um alignment on wanting to grow in our
work ethic. And I I imagine that's what
would make it hard. You know, if one
founder said, you know, I'm going to
take 6 months off and travel the world,
which is awesome. Nothing wrong with
that.
Sure.
But I think we're fortunate that there
we're completely aligned. So there's
never been a question of is this person
working hard? Does this person want to
grow it in this way? I mean, our
the problems I have with, you know,
co-founders being my brother and Laura
are that because we're so close, there's
no filter, right? Um, generally the
fights, particularly with Peter and I
are over I don't like the tone that you
took in that email, you know, and it's
like, you know, we're really not
fighting over the big stuff.
Yeah. Yeah. Was it clear early on who
would do what in this three-way
partnership?
No. No.
So, how did you sort that out?
Um, how did we sort that out?
Again, I don't remember the hard stuff.
Um, we kind of all did everything early
on. Um, as we grew, I've always been the
I never said CEO.
I always felt kind of silly saying CEO
when we were like a little business with
a few trucks. I started calling myself
the CEO when I don't know when we hit
like a few hundred employees. Before
that, there were no titles. Just we're
running the business. We're the
founders. Um, as we've grown, the
responsibilities are delineated. With
that said, it's pretty fluid. I mean,
we're growing at 30 to 40% a year. So,
nothing stays the same. The challenges
change every year.
Yeah. I mean, 30 to 40% a year off of a
pretty good size base now. Um, how big
is the business today? So in 2025, we
started with 70 corporateowned scoop
shops. We'll open 35 this year. So we'll
actually grow 50% on our scoop shop
footprint this year. Um wholesale is in
15,000 doors with over 50 SKUs. Um we I
think by July we'll hit about 2,000
total team members. Um most of that are
in the retail stores. Um, so growing
rapidly.
How did you guys grow off of those two
trucks?
By the second summer, we had six trucks.
So
from year one to two, you know, we had
gone from two trucks to six trucks. Um,
and then in the third year, an
opportunity to open a brick and mortar
rose, which was not part of our plan.
Why not? Um, we thought we loved the
truck model.
You know, you could get a truck going
There was no rent. You could put it
wherever you want. As I'm saying this,
why would you ever do brick and mortar,
right? Trucks sound so much better. You
do brick and mortar because they do a
lot more revenue and they're a lot
easier to operate. And somehow we got
this store open, which was one block
from where we lived for like $22,000.
Okay.
It was 96 ft. It was a very small store.
But you didn't need much more than that
cuz people can line up outside.
Exactly. And to us, wow, this is much
bigger than a truck, right? Bigger than
the 30 square ft.
Um,
within 3 hours, we said we're never
building another truck.
Really? Because
this was Greenpoint, Brooklyn 14, 15
years ago.
Okay. Um, so not nearly as affluent or
even residentially dense it is as it is
now.
Um, and that store in three hours had
already done the revenue that you know
our best truck location would do in an
entire day.
Why? What was different about it?
There's just something different about
brick and mortar. Like it I think it
looms in the consciousness of the
consumer in a bigger way.
And so was that the moment where you
said we're gonna we're gonna plow into
brick and mortar? Was that
we wanted to plow as much as we could
with no outside capital?
Okay.
Um we
because you wanted to stay in control of
the business or
we wanted to stay in control. We didn't
want to sell equity. I think the other
part is like
we knew we weren't good enough yet to

Um we're pretty good, right? Um but had

bucks you know which would have been

those stores would not be the way we
want them to be now
right you wanted to learn more and get

so much of what we talk about with

you jump off a cliff and you build the
plane on the way down right and and
getting started it kind Sounds like
that's a little bit of what you were

But then you took a more measured

We clearly have some product market fit,

on a rocket ship or build a rocket ship.
So what
there it feels like there are a couple
of possible inflection points here,
right? One is growing brick and mortar.
The other is going into wholesale. And
for anyone who's ever looked at the
frozen foods market, it's tough, right?
I mean, especially ice cream, it's like
it's heavy to ship. You you I mean,
you're you're you got to keep it frozen.
You can't you can't not do that. Um,
talk us through how you all evolved.
Where where where did you make a leap

It never feels like we took a leap
actually.
I mean, it feels like we're taking a

Until this year, it was kind of slow and
steady. Um,
wholesale we did not plan on going into,
but our first day in business in New
York City, somebody from Whole Foods

you know, we say yes to everything. You

You never know what's going to come of
it.
Um, you know, a lot of them end up being
a waste of time in hindsight, but, you
know, if one out of 30 is the next big

going to open, you should do them. Um,
so we said yes to wholesale, but yeah,
to what you just pointed out, wholesale
is a much harder business. If we didn't

where we'd be cuz that has subsidized
the wholesale business many many years.
Um, I mean, just looking at my wholesale

surprising to anyone with any literacy
around selling frozen CPG products, you
know, the margins are absolutely razor
thin.
Why are they so thin? Just help how for
folks who haven't been in this.
Fulfillment cost. Fulfillment means just
moving the product around. um trade
spend, which is not unique to ice cream,
but ice cream's really competitive. Um,
you know, and we're competing primarily
not with our direct, you know, small
artisal competitors, even though I think

Jerry's, the Hogands Talente, and they
are of course as efficient as you can

standpoint, and from a COG standpoint,
right? They're manufacturing as
efficiently as possible. Um,
so that makes the CPG business, you
know, really just a game of scale.
Yeah.
Right.
Was there a moment on the Vanluan
journey where you thought you might not

plenty of tough moments, you know, where

week before Christmas, maybe gosh,
probably only like 10 years ago, um
there was no finance team, you know, I
did the books and I said, "Wait a
minute,
we're going to be negative, you know,
$200,000 in a week." And I'm like,
"Shit,
not a good moment."
Yeah. Not a good moment. I don't know
how we got here, but that's not going to
work, right? Um,
we did not have any bank relationships.
There was no way to borrow money.
Somehow through a little bit of
Googling, you know, I found a
a nice, you know, 34% hard money loan.
Wow.
You know, proved in 24 hours, you know,
money was in the bank by Christmas and
it saved the day. Um,
but yeah, it was super stressful. But
even then, because before that, maybe a
month or two before that, we had turned

I was not like capital market savvy

that I knew I could pay back in a year
and a half that, you know, would cost me
like,
I don't know, 100 grand to pay back.
Yeah. You know that calculation I was so
like this is a lot cheaper.
Yeah.
Than having sold that equity. Yeah.
Thank God that's what you did.
Yeah. So we did that. Yeah. Right. So
then you all sort of famously have not

for years, right? Um and one of the ways

We sort of fell into learning about how

we ever did was Craft Mac and Cheese.
Um, it was right as the pandemic was

"Absolutely." I was like, "This is going

really cool
um of this sort of classic American

um I don't eat a lot of craft mac and

and it was really good. It's a really,

and, you know, I think within 10 minutes
the we didn't make that many initially.
Maybe we made like 20,000 bites, they'd

impressions, whatever that means. Um,
does it help the brand? I actually don't

Did you get a ton of inbound after that

We got a ton of inbound. Um, and we
actually started partnering in a way
with bigger brands
um where they would pay us to do

you know, what we learned from it,

I'm glad we did it. You know, we'll

Um, you know, New York Times last year,

Vanilla the best vanilla ice cream in

I I understand that the sort of gimmicky

Yeah, absolutely.
Um if if if Spirit Airlines came to you

What are you immediately pitching Spirit

Oh my god.
What am I immediately pitching to Spirit

I mean, I would do something that would

sort of
artisal and middle American.
So, like smoked hay ice cream.
Oh, yeah. Cuz you get the yellow in

Yeah, exactly.
Okay. Um, uh, different spirits. Spirit
Halloween. The obvious would be like a

um bitter dandelion green ice cream that

Okay, last one. LinkedIn.
Oh, LinkedIn. LinkedIn ice cream.
So something really boring.
What's cardboard made of?
Yeah.
I mean, sure, why not?
Yeah, that's it.
Okay. I love it. If we were sitting down

um two three years from now we I I I

Are you international right now or not

Not yet. We do have one location in

Um that was our little franchise test.
Um, and I mean what what excites me most

this is fun standpoint, yeah, is

What's that? The flavor lab is an

Ben, thank you for being on Masters of
Scale.
Thanks for having me. After spending

cleanText:
We bought two used post office trucks on eBay. One was five on eBay.
You bought them on eBay?
We bought them on eBay. It was click, click, deliver it here. They were about a truck. Um, and one was $2,500, one was $5,000. We found someone in Astoria, Queens to retrofit them into ice cream trucks. You know, all the credit cards were maxed out, everything. You notice on day one, we probably had, you know, $500 in our bank accounts collectively. A week before Christmas, maybe gosh, probably only like 10 years ago. Um, there was no finance team, you know, I did the books and I said, "Wait a minute, we're going to be negative, you know, $200,000 in a week." And I'm like, "Shit, not a good moment."
Yeah. Not a good moment. I don't know how we got here, but that's not going to work, right?
How big is the business today?
So, in 2025, we started with 70 corporate-owned scoop shops. We will open 35 this year. So, we'll actually grow 50% on our scoop shop footprint this year. Um, wholesale is in 15,000 doors with over 50 SKUs. Um, we, I think by July, we'll hit about 2,000 total team members. Um, most of that are in the retail stores. Um, so growing rapidly. I'm Jeff Berman, your host. This week on the show, a conversation with the CEO and co-founder of Van Leeuwen Ice Cream, Ben Van Leeuwen. He's the mad scientist behind the company's wildest flavors. You may have seen their viral Kraft Mac and Cheese or Hidden Valley Ranch ice creams online and also its incredibly delicious approach to classics. The New York Times Wirecutter called its vanilla the very best on the market. Fair warning, this episode might make you drool.
This is Masters of Scale.
Ben, welcome to Masters of Scale.
Thank you.
I, uh, I love your product. It is so much fun for me when I get to have a conversation with a founder, with an entrepreneur who, who, um, has started a company that I'm just, I, I just love. Uh, so the starting an ice cream company is not the obvious path for every entrepreneur. Take me back. Where, where did this come from?
Entrepreneurial drive. I think it's in my blood. My dad has been a serial entrepreneur since
C R I A L, not C E R E.
Yes. Yes. Yes. Exactly. Since he was in high school. Um, so yeah, I think it's part of my DNA. But Van Leeuwen Ice Cream actually came from my first summer job before college. That was the impetus. I drove a Good Humor ice cream truck where I grew up in Greenwich, Connecticut. And I loved it. I loved the hospitality aspect, interacting with people. Um, the product itself was prepackaged strawberry shortcake bars, which actually Van Leeuwen makes a Van Leeuwen version of that now, which is really good. Um, I was always partial to the Good Humor Chocolate Clair bars. Those were those were my favorites.
Yeah, really good.
Um, I did that for two summers. After the second summer of doing that, I decided I didn't want to go back to college. Um, I had saved up enough money from driving that truck to go backpacking throughout Europe and Southeast Asia.
Um, but that was a very formative experience and the decision to do that kind of changed the course of my entire life because it wasn't a rational decision like especially having grown up in Greenwich, Connecticut, an environment where it's amazing, you know, ambitious, people are interesting and um, just want to do big things. Um, but that path there, at least the way I saw it, was you go to the best college you can, you get the best grades you can, and you hopefully get a job in finance, right? Um, or maybe law or maybe medicine. Um, I never had great grades, maybe 2.8, 2.9 GPA. Um, so when I decided to go travel, you know, it was sort of the opposite of that path. And I wanted friends to come along with me. I didn't want to go alone. Like I'm a really social person. I don't do well on my own. Um, but all of my friends, you know, all these guys are still like some of my best friends on earth were like, "No, no, Ben, we can't do that. You know, this is it's going to look so bad on our resumes to take a year off college." And I was like, "But I want to do it." So, I think the lesson there was like go with what attracts. I guarantee you if I didn't go on that trip, I wouldn't have started an ice cream company.
Why? Why not? Um, a, it was formative in like learning about food and learning about really good ingredients. But more than that, why is Van Leeuwen going to open its 100th store this year? Not because we're brilliant, not because we came up with an incredibly novel product, but Van Leeuwen's going to open their 100th store this year and we're going to be the almost biggest artisanal ice cream company in the US, the biggest consumer market on Earth, simply because we decided to do it.
Yeah. I mean, I think there's a lot to be said for it's not just making a decision. It's making a decision that flies in the face of everything you've been raised to do, you've seen around you, the definition of success around you. It sounds like you really just listened to what was inside of you. And even when you couldn't persuade a friend to join you, you were like, I'm doing it. I'm going
totally.
So, on that trip through Europe, through Southeast Asia, what did you learn about food and ingredients? And then what did you learn about yourself?
What struck me the most about food, particularly like in, I remember going, you know, to the first grocery store I'd ever been to in Italy, and it wasn't a fancy grocery store. They don't really have fancy grocery stores there, yet every grocery store is almost as fancy as the fanciest store in America, 'cause I always say there's no foodies in Italy. It's just Italians, right?
Like yes, you care about your olive oil and your cheese and the quality of your pasta and that without even realizing it, then I was like, it is so, it was so exciting to me that food, this thing you do three times a day, which is something I was excited about, is normal to be excited about in other places and to care about and to put a lot of time into and to, you know, value, you know, in a really high way, right? Because I value it a lot. I mean, my, my food experience is every day. It's like, you know, some of the most important parts of my day is eating and what am I going to eat? Um, so I learned a lot about that there.
So you, you, you came back to the States from your travels. At what point did you say we're really going to do this? I'm going to, I'm going to launch an ice cream.
Well, I came back to the States for my travels. I went to college. I finished college. Um, I really looked up to my sister after college. She worked at Goldman Sachs. Then she worked at Newberger Berman, and she started her own private wealth management firm and I looked up to Jenny because she was really responsible and she made a good living and I said I want to do that and I didn't really think it through because I didn't have great grades. I'd done no internships. Um, so I said, "Jenny, can you help me get a job like one of the ones you had?" And she's like, "No, you know, she's like, I, I can try, but it doesn't work that way."
And after meeting her one day in the city, I saw Mr. Softy truck. And in that moment, um, I always say I didn't have an idea in that moment. I made a decision in that moment. So, so that's where the decision piece comes in. For some reason, I, I didn't say, "Oh, I have an idea to start an ice cream company." I said, "Oh, that's what I'm going to do." It was so clear and I was so excited. I saw this Mr. Softy truck. And by the way, I don't think this was a great idea. But I said, I'm gonna get an ice cream truck and I'm gonna learn how to make ice cream and I'm gonna find the best ingredients I can and I'm gonna sell that ice cream off this truck.
And had you made ice cream before?
No history? So I mean, where do you even start then?
Long before I had made ice cream, I started writing the business plan.
His brother Pete and his then romantic partner Laura O'Neal loved the idea too. They became Ben's co-founders.
And then once we had more confidence that we could do it, I said, "Okay, we better figure out how to make the ice cream."
What year are we in?
2007. I had Thomas Keller's Bouchon cookbook. Okay.
Um, not a pastry book, but there was a recipe for crème anglaise, which you can turn into vanilla ice cream in there, right?
And I made that and had a lot of cream and a lot of eggs. And what was really exciting about making that and tasting, we said, "Whoa, this is, you know, the best vanilla ice cream I've ever had."
Huh.
And it was really easy to make. And all it has is cream, eggs, sugar, milk, a little bit of sea salt, and whole vanilla beans.
Um, and you put it in the freezer and it stays good for months or years. So, we're like, "Wo, you can make the best ice cream ever and it's completely preservable. You don't need to add any weird stuff."
Okay. So, you, you, you've got a business plan. You've got a recipe for one ice cream.
What's, what's the leap to actually starting a company, raising money, figuring out your supply chain, all of that? Like, how did you get from A to B there?
For some reason, we came up with a quarter million is the number.
Okay.
Um, you know, it would be enough to buy a brand new Chevrolet truck, pay a lot to turn it into an ice cream truck. Um, you know, probably have a $100,000 bucks on the balance sheet to get us through the first year or two if we weren't making money.
And
we set out to try to raise money and everybody said no.
What, what were they telling you when they were saying no? What were you hearing?
It's funny. I have such a, I, I have a way of not remembering anything that I don't love.
I mean, I was, I, I was annoyed by and disappointed, but I wasn't discouraged. I was never discouraged just because
yes, I believed in myself, but also it's like I was like, I'm hardwork. I have a good pallet.
I know I'm going to be able to sell ice cream off a truck and make money. You know, I know I'll be able to pay everyone back. So, I just kept going, kept going. And I had this really beautiful business plan. It was 60 pages. And at this time, I lived in Greenpoint with Laura O'Neal, who at that time we were in a relationship.
Now, we're just co-founders and best friends on earth. Um,
I want to come back to that in a minute.
So, it was her and I, my brother Peter, and our friend, one of my best friends, Ben Colombo, all living in this apartment on Driggs Avenue. And um, McInness in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. So, I got $2,500 here, $5,000 here, 15 from a college professor, Christian Brahmer, um, 15,000 from one of Laura's best friends from Australia. My dad put in 25. So, we cobbled together only $60,000. So, we had tried to raise 250, we only raised 60. Um, and that was enough not to buy a new truck because just the new truck before you turned it into an ice cream truck would have been 70,000.
So, we bought a used post office truck. Actually, we bought two. We started with two. We because we were like, "Wait, these used trucks are cheap. Let's just get two." We bought two used post office trucks on eBay. One was 5 on eBay.
You bought them one on eBay.
We bought them on eBay. It was click, click. Deliver it here. They arrive on a truck. Um, and one was $2,500, one was $5,000. We found someone in Astoria, Queens to retrofit them into ice cream trucks. You know, all the credit cards were maxed out, everything. You notice on day one, we probably had, you know, $500 in our bank accounts collectively.
Um,
it was a ton of work though. And and what I find really striking about what we were able to do with $60,000 18 years ago is
I, I have so much more experience now. I know so much more about business. I am, you know, 50 times more sophisticated in every business department. Yet, I don't think
I could do half of what I did then with 60,000 with even half a million dollars today.
Why is that? It's a weird phenomenon.
Yeah.
I think when you're, you know, part of it is is age. When you're that young, you know, there's a different kind of energy. Part of it is an age, but it's just the hunger and the pressure to have to do it. But I mean, what we accomplish with that, like the website we built, the graphic design we did, the marketing, the product development. Um, I'm struck by how much we could do with so little.
Um, but I think this phenomenon, you know, you see it in business. This is why the Unilevers, the Nestle's cannot do what we did, you know, cannot start it even with all the resources in the world. Like when you get big, your, your brain changes. You know, you're really good. You become good at running big organizations, but harder at starting something in a scrappy way.
So you've got 60 grand, you got two trucks, you got someone in Astoria, Queens who's who's making them work for ice cream. You got 500 bucks left. How do you get to market?
Day one
we
Well, getting to day one was hard. You needed a special permit to vend in New York City, a mobile vending permit.
Mhm. And are you manufacturing in a home kitchen at this point or
you're manufacturing in a cracker in upstate New York because we didn't have any money to buy these,
you know, hundreds of thousands of dollars
recipe testing? Had you like, like where were you in your product development?
incredibly extensive and exhaustive recipe testing. So, we


Tested, for example, over 50 different chocolate recipes with 15 different kinds of chocolate, different levels of everyone. We narrowed it down to 10. So, I think we had 10 chocolates that we loved. We had 10 vanillas, we had five mint chips, we had seven gingers. Um, you know, so we had probably a hundred flavors and we invited 50 people over to our apartment and we had the greatest party ever.

Oh, it was awesome. And we had everybody fill out surveys. What do you like? What do you like? What do you like? Um, so we did really, really rigorous, you know, market testing, you know, for no money. And and that's sort of where I'm getting back. Like if Van Leeuwen were to attempt to do that now in a regular way, that study would cost $30,000 to $40,000.

You're waiting on the permit.

We're waiting on the permit. You're you've got a co-packing location up. Every week we're going to try to get the permit, but then the person doesn't show up. So, it's really discouraging and then finally after six weeks of doing this, it's late June, it's almost July, so like missed those great spring months. Um, and we knew about this because we had run the Good Humor Trucks. So, we knew, you know, you have four months of really, really good sales. Um, then finally, I think it was June 21st, we get our permit, and we are so excited. So, we get the permit on this first truck. Finally, we parked on the corner of Green and Prince and Soho. And by the time we opened the window, there was like a line of 15 people.

Um, and why'd it work, right? Why'd it work right away? The truck looked really nice. It had this beautiful solid butcher block counter. Um, so it had a homeier feel than most food trucks. And we were serving 10 flavors of ice cream. So, Hudson Valley Red Currant, Sicilian Pistachio, a really good Michelle Kazelle chocolate, but it worked, I think, because of the distinctness of the truck. And then people were happy to have a product, I think, that was so clean label, not because the label read, but because I really still believe like the best ice cream is made with just milk, cream, sugar, eggs, and, you know, a little bit of salt, but nothing else. I like it better without the stabilizers.

Did you come back to that location the very next day? Did that become the truck?

It became the location for I think our first three or four years. It was Green and Prince every day from 10:00 a.m. till 5:00 p.m., 6:00 p.m. And then Soho would kind of die cuz it was mostly retail driven. Um and then we would drive up to University and 12th Street, University and 12th or 11th, um in Greenwich Village and stay there till midnight.

Van Leeuwen started as a family business. Ben's co-founders were his brother Pete and his then girlfriend Laura O'Neal. Ben and Laura got married the same week they started the company in 2008. They divorced a few years later, but they remain co-founders. She now describes him as a best friend and business soulmate. All right, so let's talk about Laura for a second. Um, uh, you went on to marry Laura.

Yes. Um, uh, we had Estair Pell on the show recently and, uh, she talks about how 65% of startups that fail fail because of co-founder relationships falling apart. Um, you and Laura ended up getting divorced, but you talk about her as your best friend. You've remained business partners. How I I think for anyone who's been divorced, for a lot of people divorced, this is hard to imagine. How have you managed to make this work?

Um, I mean it wasn't hard at all. I mean it was effortless. Um, I mean we were very young when we got married. Laura's from Australia. Um, but we wanted to continue running the business together. We were really excited about it. Um, and we just continued being great friends and doing things together. Um, Laura and her partner Greg who are like my family have a four-year-old. Um, I'm super close with her. Um, so yeah, they're I mean we're best friends but also like family.

Was there a concern when you guys were separating on the personal side that would affect the business side?

Zero concern. Yeah. I mean I do I do hear about the stories of founder strife and I have my like you know so many gripes around you know working with my brother. It's not always easy. With all that said, the three of us are so aligned in our work ethic and knowing that we're never going anywhere. Um, but not because it's easy, right? You know, there's days where I'm like, is is this worth it? Like, is it worth it trying to build, you know, 200 ice cream stores in the next two and a half years? Um, but with that said, we're completely similar in our um alignment on wanting to grow in our work ethic. And I I imagine that's what would make it hard. You know, if one founder said, you know, I'm going to take six months off and travel the world, which is awesome. Nothing wrong with that.

Sure.

But I think we're fortunate that there we're completely aligned. So there's never been a question of is this person working hard? Does this person want to grow it in this way? I mean, our the problems I have with, you know, co-founders being my brother and Laura are that because we're so close, there's no filter, right? Um, generally the fights, particularly with Peter and I are over I don't like the tone that you took in that email, you know, and it's like, you know, we're really not fighting over the big stuff.

Yeah. Yeah. Was it clear early on who would do what in this three-way partnership?

No. No.

So, how did you sort that out?

Um, how did we sort that out?

Again, I don't remember the hard stuff. Um, we kind of all did everything early on. Um, as we grew, I've always been the I never said CEO. I always felt kind of silly saying CEO when we were like a little business with a few trucks. I started calling myself the CEO when I don't know when we hit like a few hundred employees. Before that, there were no titles. Just we're running the business. We're the founders. Um, as we've grown, the responsibilities are delineated. With that said, it's pretty fluid. I mean, we're growing at 30 to 40% a year. So, nothing stays the same. The challenges change every year.

Yeah. I mean, 30 to 40% a year off of a pretty good size base now. Um, how big is the business today? So in 2025, we started with 70 corporate-owned scoop shops. We'll open 35 this year. So we'll actually grow 50% on our scoop shop footprint this year. Um wholesale is in 15,000 doors with over 50 SKUs. Um we I think by July we'll hit about 2,000 total team members. Um most of that are in the retail stores. Um, so growing rapidly.

How did you guys grow off of those two trucks?

By the second summer, we had six trucks. So from year one to two, you know, we had gone from two trucks to six trucks. Um, and then in the third year, an opportunity to open a brick and mortar rose, which was not part of our plan.

Why not? Um, we thought we loved the truck model.

You know, you could get a truck going for $60,000. There was no rent. You could put it wherever you want. As I'm saying this, why would you ever do brick and mortar, right? Trucks sound so much better. You do brick and mortar because they do a lot more revenue and they're a lot easier to operate. And somehow we got this store open, which was one block from where we lived for like $22,000.

Okay.

It was 96 ft. It was a very small store. But you didn't need much more than that cuz people can line up outside.

Exactly. And to us, wow, this is much bigger than a truck, right? Bigger than the 30 square ft.

Um, within three hours, we said we're never building another truck.

Really? Because

this was Greenpoint, Brooklyn 14, 15 years ago.

Okay. Um, so not nearly as affluent or even residentially dense it is as it is now.

Um, and that store in three hours had already done the revenue that you know our best truck location would do in an entire day.

Why? What was different about it?

There's just something different about brick and mortar. Like it I think it looms in the consciousness of the consumer in a bigger way.

And so was that the moment where you said we're gonna we're gonna plow into brick and mortar? Was that

we wanted to plow as much as we could with no outside capital?

Okay.

Um we because you wanted to stay in control of the business or

we wanted to stay in control. We didn't want to sell equity. I think the other part is like we knew we weren't good enough yet to really scale.

Um we're pretty good, right? Um but had we scaled then you know had in year three someone said here's five million bucks you know which would have been enough to open you know 10, 15 stores those stores would not be the way we want them to be now, right? You wanted to learn more and get better. I I I love this because you know so much of what we talk about with entrepreneurs is you know look you you you jump off a cliff and you build the plane on the way down, right? And and getting started it kind Sounds like that's a little bit of what you were doing. Like we're just going to figure it out.

But then you took a more measured approach to scale. It was okay. We've got this going. We've got some traction. We clearly have some product market fit, but we want to hone this and get much better at this before we we try to jump on a rocket ship or build a rocket ship. So what there it feels like there are a couple of possible inflection points here, right? One is growing brick and mortar. The other is going into wholesale. And for anyone who's ever looked at the frozen foods market, it's tough, right? I mean, especially ice cream, it's like it's heavy to ship. You you I mean, you're you're you got to keep it frozen. You can't you can't not do that. Um, talk us through how you all evolved. Where where where did you make a leap either on the brick-and-mortar side or on the wholesale side where you were starting to see that this could be a much bigger business?

It never feels like we took a leap actually.

I mean, it feels like we're taking a leap this year going from 70 to 105 stores in, you know, a single year. Until this year, it was kind of slow and steady. Um, wholesale we did not plan on going into, but our first day in business in New York City, somebody from Whole Foods approached the truck and asked us if we did wholesale. And what we did early on and we still do it to this extent is, you know, we say yes to everything. You know, now it's we say yes to every meeting that might sound interesting. You never know what's going to come of it.

Um, you know, a lot of them end up being a waste of time in hindsight, but, you know, if one out of 30 is the next big deal or the best location you're ever going to open, you should do them. Um, so we said yes to wholesale, but yeah, to what you just pointed out, wholesale is a much harder business. If we didn't have the brick and mortar, I don't know where we'd be cuz that has subsidized the wholesale business many many years. Um, I mean, just looking at my wholesale P&L today, which like will be not surprising to anyone with any literacy around selling frozen CPG products, you know, the margins are absolutely razor thin.

Why are they so thin? Just help how for folks who haven't been in this.

Fulfillment cost. Fulfillment means just moving the product around. um trade spend, which is not unique to ice cream, but ice cream's really competitive. Um, you know, and we're competing primarily not with our direct, you know, small artisanal competitors, even though I think counterintuitively those feel like our biggest competitors, but who has all of the market share? you know the Ben & Jerry's, the Hogands Talente, and they are of course as efficient as you can possibly be from a fulfillment standpoint, from a trade spend standpoint, and from a COG standpoint, right? They're manufacturing as efficiently as possible. Um, so that makes the CPG business, you know, really just a game of scale.

Yeah.

You see through the entire space.
So all of the innovation now will happen at the point of sale where our guests come in.

Ben, thank you for being on Masters of Scale.

After spending time with Ben Van Leeuwen, it's clear why the company has been such a success.
Their humble, hardworking mindset allows them to balance high-quality products with innovative brand growth and a slow and steady approach to scale.
Also, the ice cream is undeniably delicious.
If you haven't had the chocolate caramel cheesecake, you have no idea what you're missing.
I'm Jeff Berman.
Thank you for listening.
